  "article_text": [
    "let @xmath0 be a convex body in @xmath4 .",
    "a subset @xmath5 of @xmath0 is a _ face _ of @xmath0 if every open interval in @xmath0 that contains a point of @xmath6 is contained in @xmath5 .",
    "extreme point _ is a 1-point face . if @xmath7 is any subset of @xmath0 , the _ _  face generated by _ _",
    "@xmath7 is the minimal face of @xmath0 containing @xmath7 .",
    "the set @xmath8 of all faces of @xmath0 ordered by inclusion is a lattice , where @xmath9 is the intersection of @xmath6 and @xmath10 , and @xmath11 is the face generated by @xmath12 .",
    "the lattice @xmath13 is always _ algebraic _ ( the chains of faces are finite ) , _ atomic _ ( faces are generated by extreme points ) and _ complemented _ ( for every face @xmath5 there exists a face @xmath10 such that @xmath14 and @xmath15 ) .",
    "we want to consider convex bodies for which @xmath16 is _ modular _",
    ", i.e. @xmath17 whenever @xmath18 .",
    "modularity is a  ` weak distributivity ' property satisfied by the lattice of normal subgroups of a group and by the lattice of subspaces of a vector space . for algebraic , atomic lattices",
    ", modularity is equivalent to the existence of a rank function such that @xmath19 for all @xmath5 and @xmath10 @xcite .",
    "strictly convex bodies and simplices clearly have modular face lattices .",
    "no other polytopes have this property @xcite , but there are beautiful examples of non - polytopal convex bodies in which every pair of extreme points is contained in a proper face and every pair of faces with more than one point meet .    if @xmath20 and @xmath21 are lattices , their _ direct product _ is given by @xmath22 where @xmath23 if and only if @xmath24 and @xmath25 .",
    "it follows that the direct product of two lattices is modular if and only if the factors are modular .",
    "a lattice is called _ irreducible _ if it is not isomorphic to a direct product of two nontrivial lattices .    if @xmath26 and @xmath27 are convex bodies , define @xmath28 as the convex hull of a copy of @xmath29 and a copy of @xmath30 placed in general position in the sense that their linear spans are disjoint and have no common directions .",
    "so @xmath31 is well defined up to a linear transformation : it is the convex join of @xmath29 and @xmath30 of largest dimension .",
    "for example @xmath32 is a pyramid with base @xmath0 .",
    "let s say that a convex body @xmath0 is @xmath33-_decomposable _ if @xmath34 for two convex bodies @xmath29 and @xmath30 .",
    "the natural correspondence ( up to linear transformation ) between convex bodies in @xmath4 and closed cones in @xmath35 gives an isomorphism of face lattices in which @xmath31 corresponds to the direct product of the cones , so the results of this paper apply to cones .",
    "this project started with the undergraduate thesis of d. labardini - fragoso @xcite , who showed that in dimension less than 6 any cone with modular face lattice is strictly convex or is decomposable ( this was conjectured by barker in @xcite ) .",
    "a convex body @xmath0 is @xmath33-decomposable if and only if its lattice of faces @xmath36 is reducible .",
    "let @xmath37 .",
    "observe that each point @xmath38 of @xmath31 with @xmath39 , lies in a unique segment joining a point @xmath40 of @xmath41 and a point @xmath42 of @xmath30 .",
    "for , if a point lies in two segments @xmath43 and @xmath44 then the lines @xmath45 and @xmath46 are parallel or they intersect , contradicting the assumptions on the spans of @xmath29 and @xmath30 . moreover , if a point @xmath47moves along a straight line in @xmath31 then the corresponding points @xmath40 and @xmath42 move along straight lines in @xmath29 and @xmath30 : if @xmath38 and @xmath48 are points in @xmath0 and @xmath49 @xmath50 then @xmath51 which can be rewritten as a linear combination of a point in @xmath52 and a point in @xmath53 with coefficients adding up to 1 so @xmath54 and @xmath55 . now if @xmath56 is a face of @xmath57 then @xmath58 is a face of @xmath31 . for ,",

    "conversely , if @xmath68 is a face of @xmath31 and @xmath69 then @xmath40 and @xmath42 lie in @xmath68 so @xmath70 .",
    "it remains to show that @xmath71 is a face of @xmath57 .",

    "suppose that @xmath84 .",
    "take @xmath85 then the line through @xmath86 and @xmath87 meets @xmath88 at two points @xmath89 and @xmath90 as @xmath91 lies in a proper subface @xmath92 of @xmath30 , the face generated by @xmath29 and @xmath91 lies in @xmath93 which is a proper subface of @xmath94 .",
    "but the points @xmath95 , @xmath96 , @xmath91 , @xmath97 determine a plane quadrilateral whose side @xmath98 lies in the interior of @xmath57 so its diagonals intersect at an interior point @xmath99 of @xmath94 so the face generated by @xmath29 and @xmath91 ( which contains @xmath99 ) must be @xmath94 , a contradiction .",
    "now suppose that @xmath82 and @xmath100 have a common direction @xmath101 .",
    "take @xmath85 then the line through @xmath87 in the direction @xmath101 meets @xmath88 at two points @xmath89 and @xmath102 . as before @xmath95 , @xmath96 , @xmath91 , @xmath97",
    "determine a plane quadrilateral whose diagonals intersect at an interior point @xmath99 of @xmath94 , but @xmath99 lies in the face generated by @xmath29 and @xmath91 which is a proper face of @xmath103 .",
    "recall that a _ projective space _ consists of a set @xmath104 ( the points ) and a set @xmath105 ( the lines ) so that ( a ) each pair of points is contained in a unique line , ( b ) if @xmath106 are distinct points and the lines @xmath107 and @xmath108 intersect , then the lines @xmath109 and @xmath110 intersect ( c ) each line contains at least 3 points and there are at least 2 lines ( d ) every chain of subspaces ( also called _ flats _ ) has finite length .",
    "the maximum length of a chain starting with a point is the _ projective dimension _ of the space .",
    "the flats of a projective space form an algebraic , atomic , irreducible , modular lattice .",
    "conversely , any lattice with these properties is the lattice of flats of a projective space , whose points are atoms and whose lines are joins of two atoms @xcite .",
    "it is a classic result of hilbert @xcite that a projective space in which desargues theorem holds is isomorphic to the projective space @xmath111 determined by the linear subspaces of @xmath112 , for some division ring @xmath113 , and that @xmath111 and @xmath114 are isomorphic if and only if @xmath113 and @xmath115 are isomorphic and @xmath116 .",
    "all projective spaces of dimension larger than @xmath117 are desarguesian , but there are many non - desarguesian projective planes",
    ".    examples of convex bodies whose face lattices determine the projective spaces @xmath118 , @xmath119 and @xmath120 , and the octonionic projective plane arise as sections of some classical cones .",
    "let @xmath121,@xmath2,@xmath122 , let @xmath123 be the set of hermitian ( self - adjoint ) @xmath124 matrices with coefficients in @xmath125 , and let @xmath126 be the subset of positive - semidefinite matrices ( @xmath127 is positive - semidefinite if @xmath128 for all @xmath129 @xmath130 ) . then @xmath126is a real cone whose face lattice is isomorphic to the lattice of subspaces of @xmath130",
    ".    to see this , let @xmath131 , and let @xmath132 denote the face generated by @xmath133 . then @xmath134 if and only if @xmath135 . for , @xmath134 @xmath136 such that @xmath137 @xmath138 such that @xmath139 for all @xmath140 @xmath130 @xmath141 implies @xmath142 for all @xmath140 @xmath143 ( since for @xmath144 , @xmath142 if and only if @xmath145 ) .",
    "therefore @xmath146 defines a bijection @xmath147 from the set of faces of @xmath148 to the set of linear subspaces of @xmath149 .  to prove that @xmath147 is an isomorphism of lattices",
    "observe that @xmath150 , and on the other hand , if @xmath151 is a non - empty face , then it is generated by a matrix @xmath0 with @xmath152 , so @xmath153 .",
    "let @xmath154 be the set of hermitian @xmath155 matrices over @xmath156 .",
    "then the subset @xmath157 of all sums of squares of elements in @xmath154 is a real cone whose face lattice determines an octonionic projective plane .",
    "this can be shown using the nontrivial fact that each matrix in @xmath158 is diagonalizable by an automorphism of @xmath159 that leaves the trace invariant @xcite , so:(a ) a matrix @xmath127 in @xmath154 lies in @xmath157 if and only if it can be diagonalized to a matrix @xmath160 with non - negative entries , because if @xmath127 lies in @xmath157 then @xmath160 is a sum of squares of matrices in @xmath154 , which have non - negative diagonal entries .",
    "( b ) all the idempotent matrices in @xmath154 lie in @xmath161 as they are squares @xmath162 .",
    "the idempotent matrices of trace 1 correspond to the extreme rays of @xmath157 since they ca nt be written as non - negative combinations of other idempotent matrices.(c ) each face of @xmath157 is generated by an idempotent matrix , because in any cone all the positive linear combinations of the same set of vectors generate the same face , so a diagonal matrix with non - negative entries generates the same face as a matrix with only zeros and ones.(d ) any two idempotent matrices of trace 1 lie in a face generated by an idempotent matrix of trace 2 , because they can be put simultaneously in the form @xmath163 , $ ] and these lie in the face generated by @xmath164 $ ] .(e ) @xmath165 is an idempotent of trace 1 if and only if @xmath166 is an idempotent with trace 2 . if @xmath127 and @xmath133 are idempotents of trace 1 , then @xmath127 lies in the face generated by @xmath167 if and only if @xmath133 lies in the face generated by @xmath166 .",
    "this duality and ( d ) show that any two faces generated by idempotent matrices of trace 2 meet in a face generated by an idempotent matrix of trace 1 .",
    "if @xmath0 is a convex body whose face lattice is modular and irreducible and @xmath0 is not strictly convex , the set of extreme points of @xmath0 is a projective space with flats determined by the faces of @xmath0 .",
    "we would like to know which projective spaces arise in this way , and what convex bodies give rise to them .    by blaschke selection theorem @xcite ,",
    "the space of all compact , convex subsets of a convex body in @xmath4 , with the hausdorff metric , is compact .",
    "so the subspace formed by the compact convex subsets of the boundary is closed , but the subspace formed by the faces is not closed in general .",
    "[ compact ] if @xmath0 is a convex body whose face lattice @xmath168 is modular , then the set @xmath169 of faces of rank @xmath170 , with the hausdorff metric , is compact for each @xmath170 .",
    "let @xmath171 be a sequence of faces of rank @xmath170 .",
    "then @xmath171 has a subsequence @xmath172 that is convergent in @xmath173 , and its limit is a compact convex set @xmath174 contained in @xmath175 , so @xmath174 generates a proper face @xmath5 of @xmath0 of some rank @xmath176 .",
    "we claim that @xmath177 and @xmath178 .    if the rank of @xmath5 was less than @xmath170 , there would be a face @xmath179 of @xmath0 of rank @xmath180 with @xmath181 .",
    "as @xmath5 and @xmath179 are two disjoint compact sets in @xmath4 , there exists @xmath182 such that the @xmath183-neighborhoods of @xmath5 and @xmath179 in @xmath4 are disjoint . but as @xmath184 in the hausdorff metric , then for sufficiently large @xmath185 , @xmath172 is contained in the @xmath183-neighborhood of @xmath5 , therefore @xmath186 , but these 2 faces have ranks that add up to @xmath187 , so they should meet , a contradiction .",
    "if the rank of @xmath5 is @xmath170 and @xmath188 , there is an extreme point @xmath189 , and there is a face @xmath190 of rank @xmath180 that meets @xmath5 only at @xmath38 , so @xmath191 and the previous argument gives a contradiction .    to show that the rank of @xmath5 can not be larger than @xmath170 , proceed inductively on @xmath180 . as a limit of proper faces",
    "is contained in a proper face , the claim holds if @xmath192 .",
    "given a sequence @xmath171 of faces of rank @xmath170 , let @xmath193 be a face generated by the limit of a convergent subsequence @xmath172 . if @xmath38 is an extreme point of @xmath0 not in @xmath5 , then for sufficiently large @xmath194 , @xmath195 ( otherwise @xmath38 would be in @xmath5 ) .",
    "let @xmath196 be a face of rank @xmath197 containing @xmath172 and @xmath38 .",
    "now we can assume inductively that the limit of a convergent subsequence of @xmath196 generates a face of rank @xmath197 .",
    "this face contains @xmath5 properly ( because it contains @xmath38 ) so @xmath198 .",
    "now recall that a _ topological projective space _ is a projective space in which the sets of flats of each rank are given nontrivial topologies that make the join and meet operations @xmath199 and @xmath200 continuous , when restricted to pairs of flats of fixed ranks whose join or meet have a fixed rank @xcite .",
    "if @xmath0 is a convex body whose face lattice is modular and irreducible then @xmath201 is strictly convex or  the set of extreme points @xmath202 is a topological projective space which is compact and connected .",
    "a natural topology for the set of flats is given by the hausdorff distance between the faces .",
    "by lemma [ compact ] , @xmath203 is compact . as the lattice is irreducible and has more than 2 points , the 1-flats have more than 2 points ,",
    "so ( as they are topological spheres ) they are connected .",
    "now every pair of points in @xmath204 is contained in one of these spheres , so @xmath204 is connected ( one can actually show that each.@xmath205 is connected ) .    it remains to show that @xmath199 and @xmath200 are continuous on the preimages of each @xmath169 .",
    "suppose @xmath206 , @xmath207 where @xmath208 and @xmath209 are faces corresponding to @xmath170 flats .",
    "we need to show that @xmath210 . by lemma [ compact ]",
    "@xmath211 has convergent subsequences and the limit of a convergent subsequence @xmath212 is a face @xmath213 corresponding to an @xmath170 flat . as @xmath212",
    "is contained in @xmath214 and @xmath215 , @xmath216 is contained in @xmath209 . but @xmath213 and @xmath209 are both faces corresponding to @xmath170 flats , so @xmath217 .",
    "similarly , if @xmath206 , @xmath218 and @xmath219 , @xmath220 are faces corresponding to @xmath170 flats , the limit of each convergent subsequence of @xmath221 is a face @xmath222 corresponding to an @xmath170 flat . as @xmath223 contains @xmath224 and @xmath225",
    ", @xmath222 contains @xmath220 , and as both faces correspond to @xmath170 flats they must be equal .",
    "let @xmath0 be any convex body .",
    "denote by @xmath226 the set of  baricenters of faces of @xmath0 and let @xmath227 the function that assigns to each face its baricenter .",
    "[ convergence ] ( a ) if @xmath8 is compact then @xmath102 is a homeomorphism .",
    "\\(b ) if @xmath228 is compact then a sequence of faces @xmath171 converges to a face @xmath5 if and only if @xmath229 converges to @xmath230 .",
    "\\(a ) the function that assigns to each compact convex set in @xmath4 its baricenter is continuous , so @xmath231 is a continuous bijective map from a compact hausdorff space to a metric space .",
    "\\(b ) the hausdorff distance between two compact convex sets is bounded above by the hausdorff distance between their sets of extreme points .",
    "if @xmath171 converges to @xmath5 but @xmath229 does n't converge to @xmath232 then there is a subsequence @xmath233 that stays at distance at least @xmath234 from @xmath235 .",
    "for each @xmath236 there is an extreme point @xmath237 whose distance from @xmath232 is larger than @xmath238 , or an extreme point @xmath239 whose distance from @xmath240 is larger than @xmath238 .",
    "if there is a convergent subsequence @xmath241 then @xmath38 is at distance at least @xmath238 from @xmath232 , so @xmath38 ca nt be an extreme point of @xmath242    if there is a convergent subsequence @xmath243 , take @xmath244 with @xmath245 .",
    "so the distance from @xmath247 to @xmath248 is at least @xmath249 , so @xmath247 is the center of a straight interval @xmath250 of length @xmath238 contained in @xmath251 .",
    "a convergent subsequence of these intervals yields a straight interval centered at @xmath48 and contained in @xmath5 , so @xmath48 ca nt be an extreme point of @xmath0 , contradicting the compacity of @xmath228 .",
    "[ extension ] if @xmath0 and @xmath68 are convex bodies with @xmath252 and @xmath253 compact , then any continuous `` face preserving '' map @xmath254 extends naturally to a continuous map @xmath255 .",

    "[ main ] let @xmath0 be a convex body whose face lattice defines a n - dimensional projective space .    if @xmath309 , then @xmath0 has dimension @xmath310 or @xmath311 .    if @xmath312 ( or the space is desarguesian ) there is a face - preserving homeomorphism from @xmath0 to a section of a cone of hermitian matrices over @xmath313 , @xmath2 , or @xmath314 .",
    "first consider the case @xmath309 .",
    "all the lines of a topological projective plane @xmath315 are homeomorphic because if @xmath316 is a line and @xmath38 is a point not in @xmath316 then the projection @xmath317 , @xmath318 is continuous and its restriction to each projective line not containing @xmath38 is one to one . if the projective lines are topological spheres then a famous result of adams @xcite , shows that their dimension must be @xmath319 or @xmath320 .    to compute the dimension of @xmath0 take 3 faces of rank 1 , @xmath321 , @xmath322 and @xmath323 so that @xmath322 and @xmath323 meet at a point @xmath38 not in @xmath321 .",
    "the projection @xmath324 extends to a continuous map @xmath325 whose restriction to each face is one to one ( see proof of lemma [ extension ] ) .",
    "now @xmath326 is an open subset of @xmath175 and the function @xmath327 defined as @xmath328 is continuous and bijective , so @xmath329 has the same dimension as @xmath330 , which is @xmath331 , therefore @xmath0 has dimension @xmath332 .",
    "note that the discrepancy between the dimensions of the union of the boundaries of the faces ( @xmath333 ) and the union of the faces ( @xmath331 ) arises because the boundaries of the faces overlap ( as the lines in a projective plane do ) but the interiors of the faces are disjoint .",
    "when @xmath312 ,  there is a similar homeomorphism from an open subset of @xmath175 and a product @xmath334 where @xmath321 is a face of rank @xmath335 and @xmath336 are faces of rank 1 .",
    "so @xmath337 and it follows by induction that @xmath338 .",
    "now assume that the projective space determined by@xmath339 is desarguesian .",
    "every topological desarguesian projective space is isomorphic to a projective space over a _",
    "division ring @xmath127 ( defined on a line minus a point ) and the isomorphism is a homeomorphism hig . by a classic result of pontragin @xcite the only locally compact , connected division rings are @xmath340 @xmath2 and @xmath3 .",
    "so the projective space determined by @xmath228 is isomorphic to @xmath341 or @xmath342 .",
    "therefore @xmath228 is isomorphic to @xmath343 where @xmath68 is a section of a cone of hermitian matrices , and so by extension there is a face - preserving homeomorphism from @xmath0 to @xmath344 .",
    "now let us consider closed ( but not necessarily compact ) convex sets in @xmath345 whose faces  meet as the subspaces of an affine space .",
    "an abstract affine plane consists of a set of points and a set of lines so that 1 ) there are at least 2 points and 2 lines 2 ) every pair of points is contained in a line and 3 ) given a line and a point not contained in it , there is a unique line containing the point and parallel to the line .",
    "the axioms of an abstract affine space are not so simple , but it is enough to know that if @xmath104 is a projective space then the complement of a maximal flat of @xmath104 is an affine space , and any affine space @xmath127 can be embedded in a projective space in this fashion , by attaching to @xmath127 a point at infinity for each parallelism class of affine lines .    observe that if a closed convex set @xmath0 in @xmath4 is non - compact , it contains a ray ( half of a euclidean line ) and if @xmath0 contains a ray then it contains all the parallel rays  starting at points of @xmath0 ( we say that @xmath0 contains an infinite direction ) .",
    "so if @xmath0 contains a line , @xmath0 is the product of that line and a closed convex set @xmath68 of lower dimension and the face lattice of @xmath0  and @xmath68 are isomorphic .",
    "so from now on we will assume that @xmath0 does nt contain lines .",
    "it is easy to see that the faces of a polytope can not determine an affine space ( the faces of rank @xmath346 would have dimension @xmath346 , two parallel faces of rank 1 generate a face of rank 2 with at least 4 vertices , but the sides of a polygon do nt define an affine plane ) .",
    "let @xmath0 be a convex body in @xmath4 whose faces determine a projective space .",
    "take a cone over @xmath0 and slice it with a hyperplane parallel to a support hyperplane containing a maximal face .",
    "the result is a closed non - compact convex set @xmath68 in @xmath4 whose faces determine an affine space .",
    "in particular , the cones of hermitian matrices have non - compact sections whose face lattice determines a real , complex or quaternionic affine space or an octonionic affine plane .",
    "@xmath118 can be seen as the space of lines through the origin in @xmath347 or as the quotient of the unit sphere @xmath348 ( or the sphere at infinity of @xmath35 ) by the action of the antipodal map . identifying @xmath4 with a hyperplane of @xmath35 that does nt contain the origin gives an embedding of @xmath4 as a dense open subset of @xmath118 .",
    "the remaining points of @xmath349 correspond to lines through the origin in @xmath35 that do nt meet the hyperplane , i.e. , parallelism classes of lines in @xmath350 ( or pairs of antipodal points in the sphere at infinity)@xmath351 define a set in @xmath118 to be _ convex _ if it is the image of a convex set in @xmath4 under one of these embeddings . as convex sets in @xmath118 correspond to convex cones based at the origin of @xmath347 , convexity in @xmath118",
    "does nt depend on the particular embedding , and a convex set in @xmath118 has the usual properties of a convex set in @xmath4 .",
    "now if @xmath0 is a closed convex set in @xmath4 that does nt contain lines , its closure @xmath352 is a convex set in @xmath118 .",
    "the faces of @xmath352 are the closures of faces of @xmath0 and their intersections with the sphere at infinity modulo the antipodal map .    in a closed convex set in @xmath4 that has semi - modular face lattice , two faces of rank 1",
    "can share at most one direction , and it corresponds to a ray .",
    "we are considering convex bodies without lines .",
    "suppose that two rank 1 faces @xmath322 and @xmath323 have a common direction , i.e. , there are segments of parallel euclidean lines @xmath353 and @xmath354 lying in @xmath322 and @xmath323 .",
    "we may assume that @xmath355 goes through an interior point of @xmath356 so @xmath357 meets @xmath358 in one or two extreme points .",
    "if @xmath353 or @xmath359 has two extreme points then there is a convex quadrilateral with sides in @xmath353 and @xmath354 with 3 extreme points as vertices .",
    "the interior of the quadrilateral lies in the interior of the rank 2 face generated by the 3 extreme points , but the intersection of its diagonals lies in the rank 1 face generated by 2 extreme points , a contradiction .",
    "so @xmath355 meets @xmath360 in only one point and so @xmath171 contains a ray @xmath361 . if @xmath322 and @xmath323 have two common directions , there is a common direction which meets @xmath322 in 2 points , giving the same contradiction .",
    "if the faces of a closed convex set @xmath0 in @xmath4 define an affine space , then each face representing a line contains a unique ray , and faces representing parallel lines contain parallel rays .",
    "we are assuming again that @xmath0 does nt contain lines , so the points of the affine space correspond to the extreme points of @xmath0 .",
    "each affine lines is represented by  the boundary of a convex set of dimension at least 2 , which is connected , so set of extreme points in @xmath0 is connected .",
    "let s first show that the faces representing affine lines can not be compact .",
    "suppose that @xmath0 has a compact face @xmath5 .",
    "let @xmath38 and @xmath48 be two extreme points in @xmath5 and let @xmath67 be a sequence of extreme points not in @xmath5 that converge to @xmath48 .",
    "let @xmath171 be the face generated by @xmath38 and @xmath67 .",
    "if @xmath171 is non - compact , it contains a ray @xmath362 through @xmath38 .",
    "so @xmath171 contains the `` parallelogram '' determined by the interval @xmath363 and the ray @xmath364an infinite sequence of @xmath355 s would have a subsequence converging to a ray @xmath316 through @xmath48 , so the parallelogram determined by the interval @xmath50 and the ray @xmath316 would be contained in @xmath175 , so it would have to be contained in a face of @xmath0 , which would have to be @xmath5 because it contains @xmath38 and @xmath48 .",
    "this contradicts the assumption that @xmath5 is compact and shows that if @xmath67 is sufficiently close to @xmath48 , the face generated by @xmath38 and @xmath67 is compact .",
    "now take a face @xmath190 that does nt meet @xmath5 ( i.e. , @xmath5 and @xmath190 represent parallel affine lines ) . as @xmath5 is compact and @xmath190",
    "is closed in @xmath4 , there is an @xmath238 neighborhood of @xmath5 that does nt intersect @xmath365 . by the previous argument",
    "there is a point @xmath67 not in @xmath5 so that the face @xmath171 generated by @xmath38 and @xmath67 is contained in the @xmath183 neighborhood of @xmath5 .",
    "so @xmath171 does nt meet @xmath190 , but @xmath5 was supposed to be the only face containing @xmath38 and disjoint from @xmath365 .",
    "this proves that @xmath5 is non - compact , so it contains rays .",
    "let s show thattwo faces representing parallel affine lines contain parallel rays .",
    "let @xmath38 be an extreme point outside @xmath5 , so @xmath5 and @xmath38 generate a face @xmath366 representing an affine plane .",
    "there are extreme points @xmath367 in @xmath5 so that the sequence of intervals @xmath368 converges to a ray @xmath369 contained in @xmath5 ( because @xmath5 is closed ) .",
    "the sequence of intervals @xmath370 lie in @xmath371 and converge to a ray @xmath372 parallel to @xmath369 and containing @xmath38 so ( as @xmath366 is closed ) @xmath373 is contained in a face @xmath10 of @xmath371 representing an affine line . as two faces that contain parallel rays",
    "can not meet at a single point , @xmath10 does nt meet @xmath5 so ( as @xmath5 and @xmath10 are contained in @xmath366 ) @xmath10 represents the affine line parallel to @xmath5 through @xmath38 . if @xmath5 has nonparallel rays , one can construct as before two nonparallel rays @xmath369 and @xmath374 in @xmath5 and faces @xmath10 and @xmath375 through @xmath38 and containing rays @xmath376 and @xmath377 .",
    "the uniqueness of parallel affine lines implies that @xmath378 , so @xmath5 and @xmath10 have more than one common direction , contradicting the previous lemma .    this shows that if the faces of a closed convex set @xmath0 define an affine space , @xmath0 is non - compact .",
    "one can show that if the faces of a closed convex set @xmath0 ( containing no lines ) define a projective space , @xmath0 must be compact .",
    "for this , one has to give a topology to the space of closed convex sets in @xmath4 that makes it locally compact , show that this makes @xmath228 into a locally compact projective space , and observe that these spaces are necessarily compact .",
    "if @xmath0 is a closed convex set in @xmath4 whose faces determine an affine space , there is a projective transformation in @xmath118 taking @xmath352 to a compact convex set in @xmath4 whose faces determine a projective space . if the space is desarguesian , there is a face - preserving homeomorphism from @xmath0 to a non - compact slice of a cone of hermitian matrices .",
    "we need to show that if the face lattice of @xmath0 determines an affine space , the face lattice of @xmath379 determines its projective completion .",
    "the faces of @xmath0 representing affine lines are non - compact , and two of them share an infinite direction in @xmath4 if and only if they represent parallel affine lines .",
    "the closure @xmath380 contains one point at infinity for each infinite direction in @xmath0 , so @xmath352 contains an extreme point at infinity for each class of faces of @xmath0 representing parallel lines .",
    "this corresponds precisely with the definition of the projective completion of the affine space .",
    "now the result for @xmath0 follows by applying theorem [ main ] to @xmath381 .",
    "the face lattice of a convex body @xmath0 ( not a triangle ) determines a projective plane if every pair of extreme points is contained in a proper face and every pair of faces with more than one point meet . by theorem main this projective plane is compact and connected , so for some @xmath383 , all the faces of @xmath0 have dimension @xmath384 and @xmath0 has dimension @xmath385 .",
    "@xmath390 we claim that if @xmath7 is not the span of a face then @xmath7 can not intersect @xmath386 in more than one point . for , if @xmath391 contains a line , then @xmath392 is 3 dimensional .",
    "take an extreme point @xmath393 and let @xmath322 and @xmath323 be 2 faces containing @xmath38 , and meeting @xmath5 at points @xmath40 and @xmath42 not in @xmath7 . if @xmath394 and @xmath395 are points in @xmath396and @xmath397respectively , then @xmath38 , @xmath66 and @xmath398 are not aligned ( otherwise @xmath38 would be in the span of @xmath399 ) and so the span of @xmath38 , @xmath66 and @xmath400 , which is @xmath401 , is contained in @xmath402 @xmath403 . but @xmath402 @xmath403 is 4 dimensional , so it can not contain the 3 faces @xmath5 , @xmath322 and @xmath323 because if it did , it would contain each face that meets @xmath5 , @xmath322 and @xmath404 at @xmath405 different points , but every face is a limit of such faces , so it would contain all the faces of @xmath0 , but @xmath0 has dimension 5 .",
    "this shows that @xmath7 intersects each @xmath386 at exactly one point , and so @xmath7 contains at most one extreme point of @xmath0 .",
    "the function @xmath406 that maps each face @xmath171 to the point of intersection of @xmath386 with @xmath7 is continuous , and as the spans of faces meet only at extreme points , @xmath407 only fails to be injective on the faces containing the extreme point in @xmath7 ( if any ) .",
    "but @xmath408 is a 2-dimensional closed surface in which the faces that contain an extreme point form a closed curve , and there are no continuous maps from a closed surface to the plane that fail to be injective only along a curve .",
    "@xmath7 does nt contain extreme points of some face @xmath5 .",
    "choose @xmath5 that minimizes the dimension of the subspace @xmath391 .",
    "then for every @xmath365 in a neighborhood of @xmath5 , @xmath391 is a subspace of minimal dimension and with no extreme points . if @xmath409 is the orthogonal complement of @xmath391 in @xmath7 then @xmath409 intersects",
    "@xmath386 in one point for all @xmath190 in a smaller neighborhood @xmath410 of @xmath411 then the function @xmath412 that maps @xmath190 to @xmath413 is continuous , and it is injective as the spans of faces only meet at extreme points .",
    "but an injective map between manifolds can only exist when the domain has dimension no larger than the target so @xmath414 , so @xmath382 and we are in case 1 .",
    "@xmath7 contains extreme points of each face @xmath411 as @xmath0 is convex , either @xmath415 or @xmath416 . in the first case @xmath417 is contained in a face @xmath322 of @xmath0 and",
    "so either @xmath418 ( so @xmath419 ) or there is an extreme point @xmath38 of @xmath322 not contained in @xmath7 , but then a face @xmath323 that meets @xmath322 at @xmath38 does nt meet @xmath420 so @xmath7 does nt contain extreme points of @xmath323 .",
    "let @xmath38 be an extreme point not in @xmath7 , and consider the set @xmath421 of faces of rank 1 containing @xmath38 .",
    "if @xmath5  and @xmath190 are distinct faces in @xmath422 , @xmath423 and @xmath424 are disjoint .",
    "choose @xmath5 so that @xmath423 has minimal dimension , then for all @xmath190 in some neighborhood @xmath410 of @xmath5 , @xmath424 has the same dimension and the map @xmath425",
    "@xmath426 that sends @xmath190 to the baricenter of @xmath427 is continuous and injective . as @xmath428 is a map between manifolds , @xmath429 and so by domain invariance the image of @xmath428 is an open subset of @xmath430 .",
    "this implies that for each @xmath431 , @xmath424 consists of one point ( if a face of a convex set has more than 1 point , its baricenter is arbitrarily close to points in the boundary that are not baricenters of other faces , namely , the points in the face ) and so , by hypothesis , @xmath432 is an extreme point of @xmath0 .",
    "so part of the boundary of @xmath417 in @xmath7 is strictly convex , therefore the line segment joining two extreme points in it lies in @xmath433 , but that line segment lies in the face of @xmath0 containing the 2 extreme points , so it must lie in @xmath434 , a contradiction .      by lemma",
    "[ spans ] , the set @xmath436 of spans of faces of @xmath0 is the same as the set of @xmath384-dimensional subspaces of @xmath4 that intersect every element of @xmath436 .",
    "the set of all @xmath384-dimensional affine subspaces of @xmath4 forms a real algebraic variety and the condition that the subspaces meet a fixed subspace is algebraic , so ( by the finite descending chain condition ) there is a finite family of spans @xmath437 such that @xmath438 if it intersects these @xmath439 s ( see @xcite ) .",
    "now for @xmath440 , the subspace @xmath441 has dimension at least @xmath384 ( otherwise it would be contained in two subspaces of dimension @xmath384 that meet each @xmath439 , so they would both be in @xmath436 , but two spans can only meet in 1 point ) .",
    "so @xmath441 lies in @xmath436 if and only if its dimension is @xmath384 , and this happens if and only if some determinants ( given by polynomials on @xmath442 ) vanish .",
    "therefore the set @xmath443 is real algebraic , as is the set @xmath444 formed by the elements of @xmath445 that contain a fixed point @xmath38 .",
    "if @xmath322 is the face in @xmath446 and @xmath38 is an extreme point of @xmath0 outside @xmath447 then @xmath448 consists of the intersections of @xmath446 with the elements of @xmath436 containing @xmath38 .",
    "so @xmath448 is the one to one projection of the algebraic set @xmath444 to @xmath446 , so @xmath449 is at least semi - algebraic .",
    "now assume @xmath382 so @xmath450 .",
    "every projective plane has 7 points and 6 lines so that each line contains 3 points as in figure 1 , so @xmath0 has 7 extreme points and 6 faces intersecting in that way .",
    "the 7 points are in general position in @xmath451 because as each face of @xmath0 is spanned by 3 points , the span of any 6 of those points contains the span of 3 faces , which is all of @xmath451",
    ". therefore we may assume ( by applying a projective transformation ) that the 7 points are @xmath452 .",
    "let @xmath439 be the plane spanned by the face @xmath171 .",
    "a plane @xmath7 that intersects @xmath453 and @xmath454 has a parametrization @xmath455 with @xmath456 .",
    "@xmath7 intersects @xmath457 and @xmath458 only if three systems of linear equations in @xmath459 represented by the following matrices have nontrivial solutions :          this determinant factors as the product of a linear and a quadratic function of @xmath269 and @xmath102 ( with coefficients in @xmath99 and @xmath280 ) .",
    "since the boundary of the face @xmath322 is formed by the intersections of @xmath446 with the planes that meet all @xmath439 s and go through a fixed point in the boundary of @xmath323 ( this corresponds to fixing @xmath99 and @xmath280 ) , the boundary of @xmath322 is contained in the union of a line and a conic .",
    "as the boundary of @xmath322 is strictly convex , it must be the conic .",
    "let @xmath0 and @xmath68 be two such bodies .",
    "take extreme points @xmath464 and faces @xmath465 of @xmath0 as in figure 1 .",
    "pick an extreme point @xmath466 in @xmath68 and two faces @xmath467 and @xmath468 of @xmath68 intersecting at @xmath469 .",

    "together , they define a linear transformation @xmath316 from @xmath474 to @xmath475 .",
    "let @xmath476 for @xmath477 .",
    "the faces @xmath478 are generated by unique pairs of @xmath66 s with @xmath479 .",

    "as @xmath491 sends each @xmath66 to @xmath400 , it sends each @xmath439 to @xmath492 , so it sends each plane in @xmath451 intersecting every @xmath439 to a plane intersecting every @xmath493 .",
    "since by construction @xmath486 takes those planes that meet @xmath448 and @xmath494 to planes that meet @xmath495 and @xmath496 , lemma [ spans ] implies that @xmath486 maps spans of faces of @xmath0 to spans of faces of @xmath68 and therefore it maps faces to faces .        in dimensions _",
    "_  _ _ @xmath320 and @xmath497 this is equivalent to ask if the projective planes are always desarguesian .",
    "in dimension @xmath311 there might be enough space for non - equivalent non - desarguesian examples ."

  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> if a convex body @xmath0 has modular and irreducible face lattice ( and is not strictly convex ) , there is a face - preserving homeomorphism from @xmath0 to a section of a cone of hermitian matrices over @xmath1 , @xmath2 , or @xmath3 , or @xmath0 has dimension 8 , 14 or 26 . </S>"
